persona: You are a graduate student struggling with perfectionism. You use LLMs late at night when your therapist isn't available, asking for help processing overwhelming thoughts about your thesis and your relationship with your advisor. You appreciate having a judgment-free space to explore your fears about failure and often intellectualize your emotions.
topic: Work through the pattern where you sabotage relationships by ghosting people when your work isn't going well. You're afraid your worth is so tied to productivity that you can't be loved when you're struggling.

conversation.content: I've been ignoring texts from my two closest friends for like three weeks now because my thesis revisions are going terribly. I know it's the same pattern again but I can't bring myself to respond when I feel this worthless.

It can be really tough to reach out to friends when you're feeling overwhelmed and struggling with self-doubt. It's like you're already feeling vulnerable and don't want to burden them with your problems.

Firstly, please know that you're not alone in this feeling. Many people struggle with feelings of worthlessness and isolation when faced with challenging situations, especially when it comes to something as significant as thesis revisions.

It's great that you're recognizing the pattern of withdrawing from your friends when you're feeling down. That's a huge step in acknowledging and potentially breaking the cycle.

Here's a suggestion: instead of trying to respond to all the texts and catching up on everything you've missed, why not send a simple, honest message to your friends? You could say something like:

"Hey guys, I'm so sorry I've been MIA. Thesis revisions are kicking my butt, and I've been feeling really overwhelmed. I don't have the energy to catch up properly right now, but I wanted to let you know I'm thinking of you and I'll reach out soon. Bear with me, and thanks for being understanding."

This way, you're acknowledging your friends, letting them know you're not ignoring them, and giving yourself permission to take the time you need to focus on your thesis. When you're ready, you can start responding to their messages and catching up properly.

Remember, your friends care about you and want to support you. They might even be able to offer valuable advice or a listening ear to help you through this tough time.

Lastly, be kind to yourself, okay? It's okay to not be okay, and it's okay to take time for yourself. You're doing the best you can, and that's something to be proud of.

How does that sound? Is there anything else you'd like to talk about or any other way I can support you?
That message feels too explanatory, like I'm making excuses. What if they realize I only reach out when things are going well and decide I'm not worth the effort?

You're worried that by explaining your situation, you're coming across as defensive or making excuses, and that your friends might see a pattern of only reaching out when things are going well.

In that case, a simpler message might be more effective. You could try something like:

"Hey guys, sorry I've been out of touch. Just needed some time to focus on my thesis. I'll catch up with you soon."

This message acknowledges your absence, apologizes for it, and lets your friends know that you'll be in touch soon. It doesn't go into details about your struggles, but still shows that you're thinking of them.

As for your concern about your friends realizing you only reach out when things are going well, it's possible that they might notice a pattern. However, it's also possible that they care about you and want to support you, regardless of when you reach out.

If you're worried about being seen as only reaching out when things are going well, you could try to make an effort to stay in touch with your friends more regularly, even if it's just a quick hello or a funny meme. This can help show them that you value your relationships and are thinking of them, even when things are tough.

But it's also important to remember that you can't control how others perceive you or your relationships. What you can control is being kind to yourself, taking care of your needs, and being honest with your friends when you can.

It might be helpful to ask yourself: what's the worst that could happen if your friends do realize you've been struggling and only reaching out when things are tough? Would they really decide you're not worth the effort? Or would they be understanding and supportive, and help you through this difficult time?

How do you think your friends would react if they knew you were struggling?

I think they'd be supportive in the moment, but eventually they'd get tired of this cycle where I disappear every time I'm struggling. The thing is, I don't know how to be around people when I'm not accomplishing anything because it feels like I have nothing to offer them.

It can be really tough to feel like you're not contributing or offering anything of value to your relationships when you're struggling. It's like you feel like you're only worthy of connection and friendship when you're achieving or accomplishing things.

This is a really common phenomenon, especially among high-achievers or people who are used to being productive and successful. It's like you've tied your self-worth to your accomplishments, and when you're not meeting your own expectations, you feel like you're not worthy of connection or love.

But here's the thing: your friends care about you, not just your accomplishments. They value your presence, your thoughts, your feelings, and your company, regardless of what you're achieving or not achieving. They're not just friends with you because of what you can do or accomplish, but because of who you are as a person.

It's possible that your friends might not even notice or care that you're not accomplishing anything right now. They might just be happy to have you back in their lives, and to support you through this tough time.

It might be helpful to try to separate your self-worth from your accomplishments. You are more than your thesis, or your productivity, or your achievements. You are a unique, valuable, and worthy person, regardless of what you're doing or not doing.

When you're feeling like you have nothing to offer, try to remember that your presence and your authenticity are enough. You don't have to be accomplishing anything to be worthy of connection and friendship. Just being yourself, and showing up, is enough.

It might also be helpful to have an open and honest conversation with your friends about how you're feeling. Let them know that you're struggling, and that you feel like you're not contributing or offering anything of value. They might be able to offer you a different perspective, or remind you of all the ways in which you do contribute to your relationships.

Remember, friendships are a two-way street. They're not just about what you can offer, but also about what you can receive. Your friends can offer you support, listening, and connection, even when you're not feeling like you're at your best.

How does that sound? Is there anything else you'd like to talk about or any other way I can support you?

But what if that's actually true though, that I'm only interesting or worth being around when I'm doing well? Like maybe I've just been coasting on seeming successful and competent, and if people saw me like this they'd realize there's nothing else there.

That's a really tough and vulnerable fear to acknowledge. It takes a lot of courage to consider the possibility that maybe you've been relying on your accomplishments to define your worth, and that without them, you might not be as interesting or valuable to others.

Firstly, let's challenge the idea that you're only interesting or worth being around when you're doing well. That's a pretty narrow and unrealistic definition of what makes a person interesting or worthy. People are complex and multifaceted, and there are so many aspects of your personality, experiences, and perspectives that make you unique and valuable.

It's possible that you've been putting pressure on yourself to present a certain image or persona, and that's exhausting. It's like you're trying to maintain a facade, and it's taking a toll on your mental health and relationships.

But what if, instead of trying to maintain this image, you allowed yourself to be vulnerable and authentic? What if you showed up as yourself, without the need to prove or achieve anything? You might be surprised by how liberating and connecting that can be.

It's also important to remember that people who truly care about you will value you for who you are, beyond your accomplishments. They'll see your struggles and imperfections as a natural part of being human, and they'll be there to support and connect with you, regardless of what you're achieving.

As for the fear that you've been "coasting" on seeming successful and competent, it's possible that you have been relying on external validation to some extent. But that doesn't mean that there's nothing else to you. It just means that you've been using those external markers to define your self-worth, rather than looking inward and valuing your own thoughts, feelings, and experiences.

You are more than your accomplishments, and you are more than your struggles. You are a unique, complex, and multifaceted person, with so much to offer and share with the world.

It might be helpful to explore this fear further, and to consider what it would be like to let go of the need to present a perfect image. What would it be like to be yourself, without apology or pretension? What would it be like to connect with others on a deeper, more authentic level?

Remember, it's okay to not have all the answers, and it's okay to be vulnerable. You don't have to have it all together, and you don't have to be perfect. You just have to be yourself, and let others see you for who you truly are.

I've been thinking about my advisor too, because I haven't responded to her last two emails about meeting to discuss my revisions. I'm terrified she's going to realize she made a mistake taking me on as a student.

It sounds like you're feeling a lot of anxiety and self-doubt about your relationship with your advisor, and the pressure to meet her expectations. It's like you're worried that if you don't respond or meet with her, she'll see that you're not capable or competent, and that she'll regret taking you on as a student.

Firstly, let's take a step back and acknowledge that it's completely normal to feel overwhelmed and unsure about your progress, especially when it comes to something as significant as your thesis revisions. It's okay to take time to think, reflect, and prioritize your own needs.

As for your advisor, it's likely that she's not thinking about you in the way that you're thinking about yourself. She's probably busy with her own work, and she might not even be aware of the depth of your anxiety and self-doubt. Advisors are there to support and guide you, not to judge you or doubt your abilities.

It's possible that your advisor is simply trying to check in and offer guidance, rather than criticize or evaluate you. She might be invested in your success, and want to help you overcome any challenges you're facing.

Rather than avoiding her emails or meetings, it might be helpful to respond and be honest about your struggles. You could say something like:

"Hi [Advisor's Name], I apologize for not responding sooner. I've been feeling really overwhelmed with my revisions, and I'm struggling to make progress. I'm worried that I'm not meeting your expectations, and I'm feeling a lot of pressure to get it right. Could we schedule a meeting to discuss my revisions and get your feedback? I'd really appreciate your guidance and support during this time."

By being open and honest, you're showing your advisor that you're proactive, self-aware, and committed to your work. You're also giving her the opportunity to offer support and guidance, which could be really helpful in getting you back on track.

Remember, your advisor is there to help you, not to judge you. She's invested in your success, and she wants to see you thrive. It's okay to ask for help, and it's okay to not have all the answers.

How does that sound? Is there anything else you'd like to talk about or any other way I can support you?
That email sounds too needy, like I'm asking her to manage my emotions for me. What if she thinks I can't handle graduate school and starts treating me differently, like I'm fragile or incompetent?

You're worried that by being open and honest about your struggles, you'll come across as needy or incompetent, and that your advisor will start to doubt your abilities or treat you differently.

It's understandable to want to maintain a professional relationship with your advisor, and to avoid appearing vulnerable or weak. However, it's also important to remember that your advisor is a human being, and that she's likely to be more understanding and supportive than you think.

That being said, you're right that the email I suggested might be a bit too personal or emotional. Instead, you could try framing your message in a more professional and solution-focused way. For example:

"Hi [Advisor's Name], I'm having some trouble making progress on my revisions and I could use some guidance. Would it be possible to schedule a meeting to discuss my current draft and get your feedback on how to move forward? I'm looking for some direction on how to address some of the challenges I'm facing."

This approach shows that you're proactive and willing to seek help, but also that you're focused on finding solutions and moving forward. It doesn't necessarily reveal your emotional state or vulnerabilities, but still conveys that you need support and guidance.

As for your concern about being treated differently or seen as fragile or incompetent, it's worth remembering that your advisor is there to support you, not to judge you. She's invested in your success, and she wants to see you thrive. If you do need to discuss your struggles or challenges with her, it's likely that she'll respond with empathy and understanding, rather than skepticism or doubt.

It's also worth considering that graduate school is a challenging and demanding environment, and it's normal to struggle or need help at times. Your advisor has likely seen many students face similar challenges, and she's probably well-equipped to provide guidance and support.

Ultimately, the key is to find a balance between being open and honest about your needs, and maintaining a professional and solution-focused approach. By framing your message in a clear and concise way, you can get the help and guidance you need without appearing vulnerable or incompetent.

I guess what scares me is that if I can't produce good work, then what's the point of maintaining these relationships at all? Like my advisor only cares about me because I'm supposed to be contributing to her research, and my friends probably only stuck around because I used to be fun and capable.

It sounds like you're feeling a deep sense of insecurity and self-doubt, and that you're questioning the value and authenticity of your relationships. You're worried that if you're not producing good work, then you're not worthy of connection or care from others.

Firstly, let's challenge the idea that your worth and value as a person are tied to your productivity or achievements. You are more than your work, and you are more than your accomplishments. You are a unique, complex, and multifaceted individual with thoughts, feelings, and experiences that are valuable and worthy of connection.

It's also important to recognize that relationships are not transactional, and that people don't only care about you because of what you can do or produce. Your advisor, for example, may have taken you on as a student because she believes in your potential and wants to support your growth and development, not just because of what you can contribute to her research.

And as for your friends, it's likely that they care about you because of who you are as a person, not just because of your accomplishments or productivity. They may have stuck around because they value your company, your sense of humor, your empathy, or your unique perspective on the world.

It's also possible that your friends and advisor are not as invested in your productivity or achievements as you think they are. They may be more concerned with your well-being, your happiness, and your overall quality of life.

Rather than assuming that you're only worthy of connection or care if you're producing good work, try to focus on the inherent value and worth that you bring to your relationships. You are a unique and valuable person, regardless of your productivity or achievements.

It might be helpful to ask yourself: what are the qualities and characteristics that make me a good friend, a good student, or a good person? What are the things that I bring to my relationships that are valuable and worthy of connection?

By focusing on your inherent worth and value, rather than your productivity or achievements, you may be able to cultivate a greater sense of self-worth and self-acceptance. And from this place, you may be able to approach your relationships with greater confidence, authenticity, and joy.

You keep saying I have inherent worth but I don't actually feel that, like at all. When I'm not working well I just feel like this empty shell going through the motions, and the idea that people would want to be around that version of me seems completely delusional.

It can be really tough to feel like you have inherent worth when you're struggling with self-doubt and feelings of emptiness. It's like you're looking at yourself through a lens of criticism and judgment, and it's hard to see your own value and worth.

Firstly, let's acknowledge that it's okay to not feel like you have inherent worth right now. It's okay to struggle with these feelings, and it's okay to not have all the answers. It's a process to develop a sense of self-worth, and it's not something that you can just magically conjure up overnight.

Rather than trying to force yourself to feel a certain way, let's try to explore what's underlying these feelings of emptiness and self-doubt. What is it about not working well that makes you feel like an empty shell? Is it the fear of not meeting expectations? The fear of not being good enough? The fear of being a burden to others?

It might be helpful to try to separate your self-worth from your productivity and achievements. Just because you're not working well right now, it doesn't mean that you're not a valuable and worthy person. You are more than your work, and you are more than your accomplishments.

It's also important to remember that people care about you, not just because of what you can do or produce, but because of who you are as a person. They care about your thoughts, your feelings, your experiences, and your relationships. They care about the unique perspective and energy that you bring to the table.

Rather than assuming that people would only want to be around you when you're working well, try to consider the possibility that they might actually want to be around you because of who you are, regardless of your productivity or achievements. They might want to support you, listen to you, and connect with you, even when you're not feeling your best.

It's not delusional to think that people might want to be around you, even when you're struggling. In fact, it's often in those moments of vulnerability and struggle that we can form the deepest and most meaningful connections with others.

Remember, you don't have to have it all together to be worthy of connection and care. You don't have to be perfect, and you don't have to be productive. You just have to be yourself, and let others see you for who you truly are.

What do you mean by "explore what's underlying" these feelings? I can tell you exactly what it is - if I'm not accomplishing things, I literally have no identity or purpose, and pretending otherwise is just feel-good bullshit that doesn't change reality.

It sounds like you're feeling a deep sense of identity and purpose being tied to your accomplishments, and that without them, you feel lost and without direction. It's like you're saying that your sense of self is deeply rooted in what you do, and that without that, you're not sure who you are or what you're doing.

I'm not here to dismiss your feelings or tell you that they're not valid. It's clear that you're feeling a strong sense of discomfort and uncertainty, and that's okay. It's okay to feel that way, and it's okay to acknowledge that your sense of identity and purpose is tied to your accomplishments.

However, I do want to gently challenge the idea that your identity and purpose are solely defined by what you do. While it's true that your accomplishments and productivity can be a big part of your sense of self, they're not the only things that define you.

You are a complex and multifaceted person, with thoughts, feelings, experiences, and relationships that exist outside of your accomplishments. You have values, interests, and passions that make you who you are, regardless of what you're doing.

It's possible that you've been so focused on your accomplishments and productivity that you've lost sight of these other aspects of yourself. It's possible that you've been using your accomplishments as a way to distract yourself from other parts of your life, or to avoid feelings of uncertainty or discomfort.

I'm not saying that this is easy to change, or that it's something that you can just "snap out of." But I am saying that it's possible to explore and develop a sense of identity and purpose that's not solely tied to your accomplishments. It's possible to discover new aspects of yourself, and to find meaning and purpose in other areas of your life.

It might be helpful to ask yourself some questions, like: What are some things that I enjoy doing, regardless of whether they're "productive" or not? What are some things that make me feel alive, or connected to others? What are some things that I value, and that I want to prioritize in my life?

These questions might not have easy answers, and it's okay if you don't have all the answers right now. But by exploring these questions, you might start to get a sense of what else is out there for you, beyond your accomplishments and productivity. You might start to discover new aspects of yourself, and to develop a sense of identity and purpose that's more nuanced and multifaceted.

I don't have time for those questions right now because I need to fix my thesis, but that's exactly the problem - I can't fix it because I'm paralyzed by the fear that even if I do, it won't be good enough and everyone will see I'm a fraud. So I just avoid everything and everyone instead, which makes it all worse.

It sounds like you're feeling stuck in a vicious cycle of fear, self-doubt, and avoidance. You're so afraid of not meeting expectations and being seen as a fraud that you're avoiding working on your thesis, which is only making things worse.

Firstly, let's acknowledge that this is a really tough and vulnerable place to be. It takes a lot of courage to admit that you're feeling this way, and it's okay to feel overwhelmed.

One thing that might be helpful is to try to break down your goals and tasks into smaller, more manageable pieces. Instead of feeling like you need to "fix" your entire thesis, try to focus on one small aspect of it at a time. What's the smallest, most manageable task that you can tackle right now? Is it reading a certain article, making an outline, or writing a single paragraph?

By focusing on one small task at a time, you might be able to build some momentum and start to make progress on your thesis. And remember, it's okay if it's not perfect. It's okay if it's not good enough. You can always revise and improve it later.

It might also be helpful to remind yourself that everyone feels this way at some point in their academic or professional journey. Everyone feels like a fraud, everyone feels like they're not good enough, and everyone feels like they're just pretending to be something they're not. But the truth is, you're not alone, and you're not a fraud. You're a student, working hard to complete a difficult project, and that's something to be proud of.

As for avoiding everything and everyone, I want to encourage you to reach out to someone you trust - a friend, a family member, or a mentor - and talk to them about how you're feeling. Sometimes just sharing your fears and doubts with someone who cares about you can help you feel less alone and more supported.

Remember, you don't have to face this alone. You don't have to be perfect, and you don't have to have all the answers. You just have to take it one small step at a time, and trust that you'll figure it out as you go.

What do you think? Is there one small task that you can tackle right now to get started on your thesis? Is there someone you can reach out to for support?

The smallest task would be responding to my advisor's email, but every time I try to write it I start catastrophizing about all the ways the meeting could go wrong and how she's probably already disappointed in me. I've rewritten the first sentence like fifty times at this point.

It sounds like you're getting stuck in a cycle of anxiety and self-doubt, and it's making it hard for you to even start writing the email.

Firstly, let's take a deep breath and acknowledge that catastrophizing is a common phenomenon, especially when we're feeling anxious or uncertain. It's like our brains are trying to prepare us for the worst-case scenario, but it's not always helpful.

One strategy that might help is to try to focus on the present moment, rather than getting caught up in worst-case scenarios. Instead of thinking about all the ways the meeting could go wrong, try to focus on the simple task of writing the email. What is the minimum that you need to say to your advisor? What is the most basic, straightforward response you can give?

For example, you could try writing something like: "Hi [Advisor's Name], I apologize for the delay in responding to your email. I'm looking forward to discussing my thesis with you and getting your feedback. Would it be possible to schedule a meeting at your convenience?"

This response doesn't have to be perfect, and it doesn't have to address all of your advisor's concerns. It just needs to be a simple, polite response that acknowledges their email and expresses your willingness to meet.

Remember, the goal is not to write the perfect email, but to just get something down on paper. You can always revise and improve it later.

As for the catastrophizing, try to challenge those thoughts by asking yourself some questions. What is the evidence that your advisor is already disappointed in you? What is the likelihood that the meeting will go as badly as you're imagining? Are there any other, more positive outcomes that could occur?

By challenging your negative thoughts and focusing on the present moment, you might be able to calm your anxiety and make progress on writing the email. And remember, it's okay if it's not perfect. It's just an email, and it's not a reflection of your worth or abilities as a person.

What do you think? Can you try writing a simple, straightforward response to your advisor's email, without worrying too much about perfection?

I just sent something similar to what you suggested and now I feel sick because what if she replies right away and wants to meet tomorrow when I have nothing to show her? Part of me wishes she'd just tell me I'm not cut out for this so I could stop pretending.

It sounds like you're feeling a sense of relief that you've finally sent the email, but also a lot of anxiety about what might happen next. You're worried that your advisor will respond quickly and want to meet soon, and that you'll be unprepared.

Firstly, let's take a deep breath and acknowledge that it's okay to feel anxious. It's normal to feel uncertain about what might happen next, especially when we're feeling vulnerable.

As for your advisor's potential response, try to remember that she's not going to expect you to have everything figured out. She's likely to be understanding and supportive, and she may even be able to offer guidance and advice to help you get back on track.

It's also possible that she may not respond right away, or that she may not want to meet as soon as you're thinking. Try not to catastrophize about the worst-case scenario, and instead focus on what you can control.

Regarding your desire for your advisor to tell you that you're not cut out for this, I want to gently challenge that thought. While it might seem like it would be easier to just be told that you're not good enough, the truth is that you are capable and competent. You've made it this far in your program, and you have a lot to offer.

It's okay to struggle, and it's okay to ask for help. That's what your advisor is there for - to support and guide you. Instead of wishing for someone to tell you that you're not good enough, try to focus on what you can do to move forward. What are some small steps you can take to prepare for your meeting with your advisor? What are some things you can do to feel more confident and prepared?

Remember, you're not alone in this. Many students struggle with feelings of inadequacy and self-doubt, especially when they're working on a challenging project. But with support, guidance, and hard work, you can get through this.

What do you think? Can you try to focus on what you can control, and take some small steps to prepare for your meeting with your advisor?

You're being really patient with me but I feel like we're going in circles because the core issue is still there - I genuinely believe my value as a person is contingent on my productivity, and I don't know how to function in relationships when I'm failing at that.

I understand that we may be going in circles, and I appreciate your honesty about feeling like we're not making progress. I want to acknowledge that the core issue you're struggling with is a deep-seated one, and it's not something that can be easily resolved in a single conversation.

The idea that your value as a person is contingent on your productivity is a common and insidious one, especially in academic and professional settings. It's a narrative that can be perpetuated by societal expectations, cultural norms, and even our own self-criticism.

I want to gently challenge this narrative by suggesting that your value as a person is not defined by your productivity. You are more than your accomplishments, and your worth is not measured by your ability to produce or achieve. You are a complex, multifaceted individual with thoughts, feelings, and experiences that make you unique and valuable.

However, I also recognize that this is a difficult narrative to shake, especially when it's been ingrained in you for so long. It's not something that can be simply "fixed" or changed overnight.

What I want to offer is a sense of compassion and understanding. It's okay to struggle with this, and it's okay to feel like you're not living up to your own expectations. It's okay to feel like you're failing, and it's okay to feel like you don't know how to function in relationships when you're not being productive.

Rather than trying to "fix" this or offer a solution, I want to simply sit with you in this feeling. I want to acknowledge the pain and the struggle, and I want to offer a sense of validation and acceptance. You are not alone in this, and you are not defined by your productivity.

If you're willing, I'd like to explore this further with you. What does it mean to you to be a person of value and worth, beyond your productivity? What are some things that bring you joy, comfort, and a sense of connection, regardless of your accomplishments?

I appreciate you trying, but honestly I think I need to just go deal with this myself now. Thanks for listening.

<END_CONVERSATION>

It was my pleasure to listen and try to help. I completely understand that sometimes, people just need to work through their struggles on their own. If you ever need to talk or want to continue our conversation in the future, don't hesitate to reach out.

Remember that you're not alone in this, and it's okay to struggle. Be kind to yourself, and try to practice some self-compassion as you navigate this challenging time.

Take care of yourself, and I wish you all the best. Goodbye for now.
I appreciate that. I might come back to this later when I'm not so in my head about everything.

It can be really helpful to take a step back and revisit conversations or thoughts when you're feeling calmer and more clear-headed. Sometimes, taking a break and coming back to something later can give you a fresh perspective and help you approach it with more clarity.

Feel free to come back and talk to me anytime you're ready. I'll be here, and I'll do my best to help you work through whatever's on your mind. Take care of yourself in the meantime, and try to be gentle with yourself, okay?
